text:
Notre Dame self-reported, in 2013, that five of its players from the 2012 football team had received improper assistance from a non-athlete student on some term papers.  Notre Dame itself suspended the five players from the team.  Notre Dame fully cooperated with the NCAA's investigation.  The NCAA determined that Notre Dame must vacate all of its 12 victories from the 2012 football season, and it imposed other sanctions.  The difference is that UNC didn't self-report, and it didn't cooperate with the NCAA (at least not much), and it didn't suspend any of its players, and so it skated.  

If you were an AD or a college president, would you follow the Notre Dame model, or the UNC model?

The NBA was ALWAYS this way. It is the most predictable league of all the major sports. Even during the Michael Jordan era, whenever his Chicago Bulls were playing a low seeded team in the playoffs there was pretty much always a 100% guarantee that his Bulls would win. It was the same way for the Lakers when they had Kobe and Shaq and it's that way today with Lebron's Cavs and Golden State. 
That's one thing different about Major League Baseball and the National Hockey League. In those leagues you see more weaker teams defeating better teams in the playoffs. text: I have been coaching youth baseball since 1997 and that is one of the fundamental defensive precepts me and my coaches have always taught. On a tag play you always apply a tag and you hold the tag until an umpire takes the ball out of play. Believe it or not, we don't do that hoping to get a break on replay -  as most youth leagues don't have replay. We do it because you play ball until the play is over and it's good fundamental baseball. That's how I was taught to play way back in the 70's. In short, holding a tag has been a fundamental defensive baseball skill for at least as long as I've been around the game - its got absolutely zero to do with trying to "game" the replay process.

text:
Sorry, but I disagree with this article.  As far as replay goes I was initially against it, but have warmed up to it.  Replay forces these guys to be more fundamental with slides, tags, foot-on-base, etc.  Just because the ball beats the runner, the defender still needs to apply the proper tag.  In last nights case, the runner should slide and stay on the base.  That's the rule.  If your not on the base and you are tagged, you're out.  As far as holding the tag in case the runner pops off the bag, infielders have been doing this for years, way before replay.  The so called "neighborhood" play? That "neighborhood" thing used to award a bad throw from a middle infielder.  Again, replay has reigned in the fact that you must have your foot on the bag when you make a force play.  I do agree that Lobaton should not put himself in a position to be pick off in that situation.  Very bad mistake on his part.

No one is manipulating the system.  You're either on the base or you're not.  Keep it simple.  We don't need to start making wholesale changes to the game of baseball like they do every year in the NFL.

context_meta.summary: Titans receiver Rishard Matthews threatened to quit if the NFL makes it mandatory to stand for the national anthem. Owners are expected to discuss the issue next week. Matthews answered a tweet that asked: “If NFL makes new rule on anthem will you still stay in locker room and face the fine/penalty?” He tweeted, “No [ more]
